BE11:25am

Today’s update is clearly i) more broadly anticipated with considerable speculation at the time of the results that risk was building to the downside and ii) smaller in terms of revisions than March last year - that prior warning saw 2-4% revenue decline guidance revised to a 6-9% decline (with 9-12% anticipated in the first half of that year). Unlike last time, there is no commentary on profitability in today’s statement. However, with Micro Focus working hard to maximise cost take-out, we suspect there will be a nearly full drop through of gross profit impact of the revision to the adj. EBITDA.

As we discussed at the fairly recent H1 results, Micro Focus: Steady ship, but lacking H2 catalyst (10/07/19), 2H19 does have a much tougher comparative than the first half of the year and, with some emerging issues in the security portfolio, this was putting some pressure on at least the mid-point of guidance. With a 5.4% decline in 1H19, the new guidance would imply a roughly 7-10% decline in H2. The focus will also be on FY20, where the market was expecting a return to a ~3% decline and clearly this is important to underpinning the valuation. We fear that it will be some time until we have a better sense of what the company will be budgeting for next year.

Finally, the company has also announced a strategic review to look at operational, strategic and financial options for the business. There is no conference call this morning to discuss this in more detail, but we expect that , given Micro Focus’ bold approach to such things, that all options will be on the table. This may provide valuation support over the coming months, but today investors are likely to question whether the strategic review itself implies issues are likely to take some time to resolve.

While Micro Focus still looks cheap on headline P/E, it has, in our view, reached fair value on an enterprise basis and we therefore downgraded to Equal Weight in our note European Software & IT Services Q1 preview: So far so good (12/04/19). Our £20 price target is based on 12x our FY20E EV/NOPAT.

Amigo Holdings (AMGO) has published 1Q19 results for the three months to 30th June 2019 this morning. We have reviewed the release and have spoken with the company. In short, it is not a pretty update – with a material miss on impairments and operating costs as well as the new CEO, Hamish Paton, taking out the red pen to current year guidance. Our first thoughts are that the stock will face aggressive selling pressure in early trading – despite significant weakness in the share price in recent months as well as a sudden significant dip in late trading yesterday.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Net loan growth came in at +2.9% q/q (+14.1% y/y), which represents a modest pick-up from the sluggish q/q net loan growth of 1.7% reported for 4Q18. This is consistent with our expectations (and previous company guidance) as our preview email to you on 28th August noted. This drove strong revenue growth of 13.7% y/y to £71.5m for the quarter. However, Impairments Revenues (excl. debt sales) came in at 30.5% for 1Q19 – which was materially above the 25.0% number reported for 4Q18 (and the 25.4% number reported for 1Q18). The uptick in impairments was driven by: i) operational challenges in collections (see below); ii) the impact of higher originations (but surely this was predictable); and iii) more cautious provisioning assumptions due to macro uncertainties. Getting back to the collections point, the company has flagged that the in-house collections team has struggled to cope with the fast growth recorded in recent years (though we worry that the “challenges within collections” could also have something to do with borrower financial circumstances). Finally, the other key point of focus within the numbers is the higher Cost Income ratio – 23.4% up from 17.5% in 1Q18, with AMGO noting that accelerated investment and a provision for complaints (we have cautioned you on FOS complaints) drove the increase.

Irish HF guy Amigo cites : Worsening macro economic environment ; Increased probability of a `no-deal` Brexit ; Growth in consumer credit continues to slow
BE11:34am

Guidance has been slashed for FY19; no guidance provided for later years
The new CEO has taken the opportunity to slash FY19 guidance in what is his first results outing. AMGO is now guiding for “broadly flat” growth in net loans – a significant departure from the previous low-teens net loans growth guidance for the medium-term (which our readers will know we never saw as credible beyond FY19F anyway). A reduced appetite for repeat loans (the regulator has flagged its concerns in this vein) underpins the change. AMGO is also now guiding for Impairments / Revenues in the low to mid-30s for FY19F, an abrupt increase from the mid-20s. We also note that no guidance beyond FY19F has been provided due to economic uncertainties. We will attend the results presentation at 09:30 and reflect on our forecasts – there is less downside to our medium-term growth forecasts than consensus but we anticipate material eps downgrades nonetheless.

Key points:
Q1 Results: Large PAT miss, loan book in-line. AMGO has reported Q1
PAT of £20.4m, 26% lower than RBCe, and down 8% on PY. Revenue was
lower than we expected whilst operating expenses and impairments were
higher. Higher impairments are attributed to 1) challenges with collections
2) higher originations and 3) more cautious IFRS 9 assumptions on new
business. Originations of £113m were 6% higher than we had expected,
although proposed actions with respect to relending and credit policy
(more below) mean we now expect lower originations overall in FY 2020.
Adapting to developments in operating environment. New CEO Hamish
Paton has announced a series of actions that we see as adapting
the AMGO business model to address developments in the regulatory
narrative and macroeconomic environment. These developments have
contributed to the market uncertainty surrounding the wider consumer
credit sector in 2019 (AMGO, PFG and NSF shares are down on average
36% YTD in 2019, versus FTSE 100 up 10%).
Key strategic actions. 1) new consumer lending to be prioritised
over relending 2) enhancement and tightening of credit policy and
3) investment in operations compliance and complaints. The proactive
approach taken to relending, for instance, demonstrates that AMGO is
prepared to listen to the regulator and stay ahead of developments. This
is the correct approach to managing the business over the long term, in
our view.

BE11:38am

Updated guidance likely to prompt consensus downgrades. Anticipated
strong demand for guarantor loans means that AMGO still expects new
customer numbers to grow; however, management has revised down
guidance for FY 2020 (but not beyond) on net loan book growth, and
expects a higher impairment ratio and cost:income ratio (see full guidance
details in Exhibit 3).
Estimate and price target changes. Our updated 2020E EPS of 15.5p
reflects the updated company guidance; we also reduce our 2021 EPS
estimate (by 34%) and DPS by 23% and 34% respectively. These reductions
lead to a mechanical decrease in our price target down from 325p to 235p.
Given implied upside in our valuation we retain our Outperform rating.

We believe HomeServe can deliver best-in-class earnings growth, led by a Membership business with underappreciated potential to combine greenfield and product expansion with increasing operating leverage, and supported by a Home Experts platform disrupting the UK market for home services and improvements. With this note we launch a new model, transfer coverage, and upgrade to Buy (Price Target: 1,350p). We are c4% above FY21e consensus, but sit further ahead for FY22e; we think the current share price anticipates a miss vs targets in one or both of the US and Home Experts.

We believe the market to be undervaluing growth prospects in both Membership (led by the US) and Home Experts, and both are contained in our base-case DCF valuation. However, recent investor attention has focused on the online platform optionality offered by Home Experts, despite this remaining relatively small in a Group context. We therefore decompose our DCF valuation into these two sides of the story, as shown above. Following the recent sell-off, however, we believe the market is attributing as little as £250m EV to Home Experts (i.e. c2x EV/Sales vs peers historically trading on 2-7x), and therefore c£3,750m EV for Membership and c18x EV/EBITA – only in-line with the average valuation for the 'defensive growth' peer group despite offering above-average growth
